ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Economic history of Latin America. Also spent a few weeks on more recent developments due to COVID-19. Paired up, the two phases allowed us to make predictions and develop recommendations for how to create growth and foster development.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Student presentations took too much time out of the 2 hour seminar. We would have preferred more lecture time by Prof. Zedillo in order to hear about his own experience and opinions on the different economic eras and strategies, rather than extensive recaps by students of the readings we had all already done. 

The readings were usually very interesting and well-chosen. Guest speakers were engaging and relevant.
No course feedback but good discussions
The virtual setting made this course really a challenge. I think that it was hard to connect with the professor and your peers on the group projects. There was also no feedback throughout the term.

Strengths: Interesting content, great syllabus, excellent guest lecturers. Cons: Could have used more support from Professor Zedillo, especially in the first half of the course, in interpreting and explaining readings. Probably too much dependence on student lectures.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'm sure that if the course can meet in an in-person format, discussions would have been more candid and vivid. Some students may not find it very easy to interact and participate in a virtual format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! To listen and learn from President Zedillo's experience is amazing.
Yes if you are interested in the topic and want to learn from someone who has dedicated their life to it. Don't expect much feedback.
Only if highly interested in the subject matter.
